text: Typically only used in the negative: невтерпеж (low: to be unbearable). So, here: bearable. Alexander Boguslawski notes that variations on this word are used in four key moments in the novel (R155, 157, 225, 254/E12, 14–15, 132, 185) and that the "close parallels between the first and last use of the phrase should be noted — this is the frame within which two other versions of the expression exist. These two framing elements are built around the word *nevterpezh*, a colloquial adverb, usually used after a noun or pronoun in dative case and often with auxiliary verbs to be or to become. Thus, the expression "mne stalo nevterpezh" [it became unbearable to me; I could not stand it any longer], [sic] is common. However, Sokolov makes some important alterations to the expression — first, he discards the dative government and substitutes another verb for the auxiliary" ("How Sokolov's" 218).

text: A central passage in the novel. Krylobyl suggests that time functions differently depending on one's location or perspective. Just as a river flows at different speeds, so does time move differently. In the backwoods, where not much happens, time moves slowly. In the city, where there is action and hustle and bustle, time moves quickly. Thus, if Ilya were to move to the other side of the river, he would be able to recover his crutches, where their theft, allegedly, hasn't yet occurred. This view of time serves as one explanation for the various contradictions in the novel. For a consideration of Sokolov's atypical approach to time in his novels, see Boguslawskii 1989.

Dated: February. бок (side) + греть (to warm). As Boguslawski translates it, "side-warmer," meaning a shift in weather that will warm your sides. A reference to St. Sidor Bokogrei, whose day is celebrated on May 14/27. He was given this name, because it was said that bitterly cold northern winds would stop blowing on this date. Likewise, swifts and swallows would fly to Sidor with the approach of warm weather. However, people caution against taking the appearance of the first bird as a sure sign of the cold's departure, similar to the following clause. Read his saint's life [here](https://religion.wikireading.ru/100944). The addressee of Ilya's letter is, of course, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh. Animal motif.

Apart from the obvious sections of literary parody in which Gogol' is flagrantly apparent, it is difficult to point to direct stylistic sources. Sokolov, however, denies having read Belyi at this point. A more likely literary context is afforded by modernist Boris Pilniak [...] Pilniak had recently been rehabilitated and his work was easily available. Sokolov recalls reading his work in 1975. Something of the same dark violence and fractured language is also to be found in the work of Pilniak's adherent Andrei Platonov whose work was being rediscovered and republished in the late 1960s" ("Background Notes" (336–337).
